lines.text: Anyhow, I used to heard it said you boys who rode with Hood drank five states dry. You could always tell where Hood's Texans had been by the empty bottles and the dead Yankees.
If I don't get to a doctor, I'll die!
It looks that way.
Apaches don't leave tracks unless they got a reason.
I've seen Comanches in Texas. And boy, I'll never want to see one again... I can tell you that.
Well, you don't see Apaches. You don't hear 'em and you don't see 'em. It's like an act of God.
All we got here is a handful of nothing... dirt and dry mouths.
I don't want to bury him here. It's an empty place... empty... nothing to remember.
You know, one thing I never could fathom was this... how did them Yankees win?
They had more... more men, more guns, more food, more luck. You know, when I look back at it, I know now that it was there for the seeing... except we didn't see it.
[on the Civil War]
Hell, it was a good war.
Harvey, I bet that horse tastes better than he rides.
Nye, you would have your own mother in a skillet before she got cold.
It's a hell of a place to die in.
There ain't no good places.
I ought to woop you.
But you won't, Jubal, because you know I'd put a hole in your gut.
Maybe he isn't a killing man.
He's half Apache, isn't he? You mix a dog and a wolf, you wind up with a killing animal.

To you this is so much bad land - rock, scrub, desert and then more rock. A hard land that the sun has sucked all the good out of. You can't farm it and you can't carve it out and call it your own... so you damn it to hell and it all looks the same. That's our way. To the breed, now, it's his land. He don't expect to give him much and he don't force it none. And to him, it's almost human - a living thing. And it will give him a good place to make his fight against us.
After your first cup, Harv, you're blind anyway. And after your second, you're darn glad you're blind!
I'm gonna kill you, Mex. Understand? And that's a promise.
I'll tell you, Brother Earl, you got some sweet disposition - all sun and little white flowers.
For a thirsty man in a dry land, you gotta lotta talk.
